newsitem.title: PORTUGAL: FOCUS-Portugal may privatise 27.5 pct of EDP.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Portugal may privatise 27.5 pct of EDP.

text.p: Portugal was expected to privatise a stake of some 27.5 percent in utility EDP-Electricidade de Portugal, including a "green shoe", its president Antonio de Almeida said on Friday.

Almeida, speaking at a roadshow to promote the sale, said it was likely a 25 percent stake in the company would be sold off, as well as a 10 percent stake of the tranche to be sold in the domestic and international direct sale in a "green shoe."
Under a "green shoe" option, additional shares may be allocated to institutional investors if demand is very heavy.

The Socialist government was expected to sell 55 percent of the 27.5 pct stake in a public offer to sell (OPV) and 45 percent in the domestic and international direct sale at a special session on Lisbon bourse on June 16, Almeida said.
EDP, Portugal's dominant electricity generator and distributor, has a capital of 600 billion escudos ($3.5 billion).
The share price in the second stage privatisation of EDP will be substantially higher than in the first stage, reflecting expectations of improved results, Almeida said.

"With the prospect of an improvement in EDP's results, I expect that in the second stage privatisation the sale will take place at a much higher price," he said. "The state will bring in a substantially larger sum (in the second stage)," he added.
Investors in the OPV could receive some 10 percent of the shares they apply for, Almeida said.
"We are four days into the pre-registration period. If demand continues at this pace, and if the publicity campaign draws in more Portuguese, I think a 10 percent figure is not unrealistic," he said.

But he said it was too early to make accurate forecasts of the total level of demand. "Much of the demand is driven by the fact that many people think that they will receive a small proportion of the shares that they apply for," he said.

A banking source told Reuters on Thursday that applications had been submitted in the first three days of pre-registration for 642 million shares, representing more than four times the number of shares likely to be on offer.
EDP said its first quarter consolidated net profit had risen by 21 percent to 29.16 billion escudos ($171 million).
The utility plans to compete for a third mobile phone licence in Portugal, Almeida said.

"We will compete for the third licence, with a national and an international partner, but I cannot give names," Almeida said at the start of a national roadshow to promote the partial privatisation of EDP next month.
"The national partner is not from the telecommunications sector, but the international partner is," he added.
The two present mobile phone licence holders are Telecel-Comunicacoes Pessoais and TMN, a unit of Portugal Telecom.
EDP had suspended talks with a view to taking a possible 20 percent stake in Telecel, Almeida said.
"Talks with Telecel did not reach an agreement," he said. "We reached the conclusion that it was preferable not to pursue the talks," he added.
